ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Critical thinking; how to reconstruct a philosophical argument; how to read and write philosophy papers.
Introductory survey course for early modern philosophy. You read texts from Descartes, Leibniz, Locke, Berkeley, Hume, Reid, Shepherd, and Kant.
learned the ideas of modern philosophers
some stuff about philosophy
Survey course of the philosophers from Descartes to Kant, with a focus on epistemology
My writing skills definitely improved. Philosophy writing is definitely different than more conventional writing and I thought this course helped me improve my writing skills.

I learned about the history of early modern philosophy, particularly the ways in which philosophers built upon their predecessors' ideas to advance the studies of metaphysics and epistemology. I also learned how to become a better argumentative writer, as well as how to analyze the large amount of readings we had throughout the semester.
Learned quite a bit about the metaphysical, epistemological, etc. views of early modern philosophers. Developed ability to write philosophy and respond critically to arguments.
Good knowledge of intro philosophy
Writing and analytic skills
This course was a good introduction to various modern philosophers, as well as philosophical thought in general.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The assignments were fair, but we did not spend equal time on each thinker.
Lectures were very sporadic and hard to follow
theres very few assignments and feedback to ensure you are actually learning the material
It's a big of a mixed bag because the lectures are not that easy to follow and are not the most engaging, but this can be made up for with a really good TA
Sometimes the information was presented in an unclear manner, probably because the philosophy text is not simple. Since it was online, it was harder to really engage in the lectures.

The course was great in providing a comprehensive view of early modern philosophy. Additionally, lectures really clarified readings that were oftentimes extremely dense. Because it was an online class, engagement during lectures was very low. It may have been helpful to allow students to ask questions or engage with the course material during lectures.

Strengths: section was great, readings were interesting

Weaknesses: Not nearly broad enough for a survey course--some of the most interesting aspects of modern philosophy were never discussed. Topics covered were incredibly challenging for a survey course. Lectures were virtually incoherent.

Strengths: you will learn how to become a much better writer after taking this course.
Weakness: The readings are very tough
The course was well-organized and engaging! I feel that there could've been more discussion on how to write philosophy papers for students who haven't taken a philosophy course before.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I do not love live virtual lectures, and I did not really understand why this course had mandatory live attendance. No one asked questions or used the chat function on Zoom.
Lectures shouldve had a better focus
the recordings were nice for reviewing material

I think that the communication/providing of resources was really good. Even though the content was confusing, I thought that the course still provided the necessary info and tools to better understand. For example, there were handouts that made it easier to follow along.

Success: section was great

Improvement: Prof DeRose may be a good lecturer in person, but was incredibly hard to follow online.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! However, it is difficult, insofar as all philosophy is (to my STEM brain) really difficult. Still, it was worth the challenge.
Take this course if you need it for the philosophy major. Otherwise, there are probably better settings in which you can get acquainted with these thinkers/topics.
Neutral.
only if you are really genuinely interested in philosophy

The student should be prepared to really engage with the content in order to not get lost. Philosophy is a tough subject because there are so many nuances but can be rewarding/enjoyable if the student likes a challenge.

I would recommend this course to any student interested in philosophy. The readings can be very difficult to get through and the writing style can take some time to get used to, but the information learned and skills gained from this course was very rewarding.
If taught by Prof DeRose... no shot.
Yes. A bit frustrating that the philosophy major requires this specific class and does not accept substitutes for modern philosophy, but a good class nonetheless
Yes, but only if they have a genuine interest in modern philosophy.
Yes! I would recommend this class to anyone interested in a survey course for modern philosophy.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments:
- Live virtual lecture
- Live virtual discussion section
Live virtual lectures
Live lectures and live discussion sections
also recorded
Lecture was also recorded
Live virtual lecture and a live virtual discussion section.
live virtual discussion section
Live virtual lecture and virtual discussion sections
Live section.
We also had live virtual section meetings.
